header.text: Towards High-Fidelity VR Simulation of HRI Tasks

Problem:: Traditional construction education often lacks training in Computational Thinking (CT) needed for modern, technology-driven workplaces involving robotics and Human-Robot Interaction (HRI).
Goal:: To develop and evaluate a Virtual Reality (VR) training environment designed to integrate CT as a core competency for construction students through immersive HRI scenarios.
Key Research Questions:: 1. How effective is the VR-based HRI training environment in enhancing specific Computational Thinking (CT) competencies (decomposition, pattern recognition, abstraction, algorithmic thinking) among construction students?
2. What is the impact of the VR training on students' skills (e.g., accuracy, speed, safety) and attitudes (e.g., confidence, persistence) related to robotic construction tasks?
3. How well do skills and CT competencies acquired in the VR training transfer to novel simulated environments (realistic terrestrial and extraterrestrial construction sites)?
4. What relationships exist between CT knowledge, attitudes, and skill performance within this VR training context?
Approach:: Developed a VR training environment featuring pick-and-place tasks with a robotic arm on a Mecanum wheel platform.
Created progressive difficulty levels across diverse scenarios (terrestrial/extraterrestrial).
Implemented a Knowledge-Skill-Attitude (KSA) framework for comprehensive assessment.

items: Level 1: Basic pick-and-place with static obstacles

VR Development:: Unreal Engine environment with high-fidelity physics
Custom textures and models for construction elements
Optimized performance for smooth VR experience
Precise collision detection for accurate task assessment
Robotic System Simulation:: Accurate kinematic model of robotic arm
Real-time force feedback during object manipulation

header.text: Towards High-Fidelity VR Simulation of HRI Tasks

CT Components Implemented:: Decomposition: Breaking complex pick-and-place tasks into subtasks
Pattern Recognition: Identifying efficient movement sequences
Abstraction: Creating simplified models for task execution
Algorithmic Thinking: Developing step-by-step procedures for optimal paths
Assessment Framework:: Knowledge assessment through CT concept application surveys
Skill measurement via task performance metrics
Attitude evaluation through confidence and persistence surveys
Comprehensive evaluation of CT competency development

header.text: Towards High-Fidelity VR Simulation of HRI Tasks

Current Limitations:: Small sample size (five participants) limits statistical power
Fixed difficulty progression may not adapt to individual learning rates
Limited variety of construction scenarios and tasks
Current focus only on pick-and-place operations
Future Development:: Adaptive learning mechanisms for personalized training
Expanded task variety beyond pick-and-place operations
More complex construction scenarios with greater realism
Multi-user collaboration capabilities for team training
Integration with physical robots for hybrid training approaches

header.text: Towards High-Fidelity VR Simulation of HRI Tasks

System Effectiveness:: VR environment successfully enhanced CT competencies
Virtual robotic system provided effective training platform
Progressive task structure facilitated skill development
Performance metrics demonstrated clear improvement trends
Results validate the technical approach and system architecture
Impact:: Provides foundation for future construction training systems
Demonstrates viability of VR for technical skill development
Creates pathway for extraterrestrial construction training
Establishes framework for CT integration in technical education
